No. F.-12 (5)-Ex.-I/37. —In exercise of the power conferred by sub-rule (2) of rule 33, rule 37 and rule 44 of the Civil Services (Classifica tion, Control and Appeal) Rules, the Governor General in Council is pleased to make the fol lowing rule: — RULE. Persons other than those to whom the rates ot pay and the revised rates of pay referred to in rule 3 of the Revised Rates of Pay Rules, apply, shall on transfer from one service, post or post outside the time-scale to another service, post or post outside the time-scale, be entitled to the old rates of pay when holding posts which carry both old and revised rates of pay. In exercise of the powers conferred by clause (&) of subsection three of section two hundred and seventy three of the Government of India Act nineteen thirty five, and by subclause two of clause fourteen of the Government of India (Commencement and Ttan^itory Provisions) Order nineteen thirty six, the Secretary of State, with the concurrence of the majority of votes at a meeting of the Council of India held this 16th day of March nineteen thirty seven, hereby makes the following rules which shall come into operation on the first of April nineteen thirty seven, namely :— '' The Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund (Untransferred Section.) Provisional Rules. 1. {i) These Rules may be called the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund (Untrans- ferred Section) Provisional Rules. {H) They apply to all persons who being on 31st March 1937 subscribers to or beneficiaries Under the Rules of the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund, had made on that date or earlier, or who have subsequently made or may hereafter make with the concurrence of the Secretary of State for India, objection to the vesting of their interest in Commissioners in accordance with the provisions of Section 19 of the Government of India (Family Pension Funds) Order, 1936. 2. {i) Every such subscriber shall make as from 1st April 1937, any contributions required by the Rules of the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund in force on 31st March 1937, at the rates and under the conditions laid down in those Rules. {ii) There shall be paid to every such bene ficiary, and to the dependants of every such subscriber after his death, benefits at the rates and under the conditions laid down in the Rules aforesaid. 3. {%) The money in the hands of the Gov ernor General in Council on 1st April 1937 representing the interest of the subscribers and beneficiaries aforesaid shall be credited to an account entitled the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund (Untransferred Section) Account. {ii) All sums contributed or paid by sub scribers shall be credited to the above account and all payments of benefit or otherwise which the Secretary of State may decide to be properly chargeable against the Fund shall be debited thereto, (m) There shall be credited to the said account in respect of each half year interest on the baiance standing to the credit of the account at the beginning of such half year at such rates as may from time to time be fixed by the Secre tary of State. {iv) The balance standing to the credit of the said account shall be a sterling liability of the Revenues of the Governor General in Council. \ In „ th ? t? Resolution. In exercise of the powers conferred by clause (&) of subsection three of section two hundred and seventy three of the Government' of India Act nineteen thirty five, and by subclause two of clause fourteen of the Government of India (Commencement and Transitory Provisions) Order nineteen thirty six, the Secretary of State, with the concurrence of the majority of votes at a meeting of the Council of India held this 16th day of March nineteen thirty seven, hereby makes the following rules which shall come into operation on the first of April nineteen thirty seven, namely :— ' The Superior Services (India) Family Pension Fund (Untransferred Section) Provisional Rules. 1. (i) These Rules may be called the Superior Services (India) Family Pension Fund (Un transf erred Section) Provisional Rules. (ii) They apply to all persons who being on 31st March 1937 subscribers to or beneficiaries under the Rules of the Superior Services (India) Family Pension Fund, had made on that date or earlier, or who have subsequently made or may hereafter make with the concurrence of the Secretary of State for India, objection to the vesting of their interest in Commissioners in accordance with the provisions of Section 19 of the Government of India (Family Pension Funds) Order, 1936. 2. (i) Every such subscriber shall make as from 1st April 1937, any contributions required by the Rules of the Superior Services (India) Family Pension Fund in force on 31st March 1937, at the rates and under the conditions laid down in those Rules. (ii) There shall be paid to every such bene ficiary, and to the dependants of every such subscriber after his death, benefits at the rates and under the conditions laid down in the Rules aforesaid. 3. (i) The money in the hands of the Gov ernor General in Council on 1st April 1937 representing the interest of the subscribers and beneficiaries aforesaid shall be credited to an account entitled the Superior Services (India) Family Pension Fund (Untransferred Section) Account. (ii) All sums contributed or paid by sub scribers shall be credited to the above account and all payments of benefit or otherwise which the Secretary of .State may decide to be properly chargeable against the Fund shall be debited thereto. (m) There shall be credited to the said account m respect of each half year interest on the mean of the balances standing to the credit oi the account at the beginning and end of such half year at such rates as may from time to time be fixed by the Secretary of State. ' (w) The balance standing to the credit of the said account shall be a sterling liability of the revenues of the Governor General in Council.3 4. In the foregoing Rules the term ' sub scriber ' shall be construed as including any person who has in the past made contributions to the Fund and whose dependants are entitled to benefit under the Rules thereof.' No. D.'lOSl-Ref./ST. —In exercise of the powers conferred by sub-paragraph (3) of para graph 11 of the Government of India (Audit and Accounts) Order, 1936, the Governor General is pleased, after consultation with the Auditor General of India, to make the following rules: — 1 . (1) These rules may be called the Initial and Subsidiary Accounts Eules. (2) Thev shall come into force on the 1st April 1937. 2. In these rules— (1) 'Initial Accounts' means a primary record of all money transactions affect ing the revenues of the Federation or of any Province as they occur; (2) the Order means the Government of Indif? (Audit and Accounts) Order, 1936; (3) 'Treasuries' includes all treasuries and sub-treasuries whether under the control of the Federation or of a Pro vince; and other terms and expressions have the same meanings as have been assigned to them in the Order. 3. The Auditor General of India from the date these rules come into force shall be relieved from the responsibility for keeping accounts of the undermentioned class or character; — (a) Initial Accounts required to be kept in treasuries ; (&) Initial and Subsidiary Accounts that may be required to be kept in any office or department of the Federation, or, as the case may be, of any Pro vince ; (c) accounts of stores and stock that may he required to be kept in any office or department of the Federation or of a Province by order of the Governor General or of the Governor of the Province; and (d) Trading. Manufacturing and Profit and Loss Accounts and balance sheets and. any other subsidiary accounts that may be required to be kept by Order of the- Governor General or of the Governor - of a Province in any Department of the- Federation or of the Province. 4. Nothing contained in Rule 3 shall be con strued as derogating from the authority of the- Auditor General of India— (а) to require any treasury, office or depart ment keeping initial or subsidiary accounts to render accounts of such transactions as are included in them to- the audit and accounts offices under his- control on such dates as he may deter mine; or (б) to prescribe the form in which such' accounts shall be rendered and in whicha the initial accounts, from which the- accounts so rendered are compiled or on. which they are based, shall be kept, J. It should also be carefully noted that the Government of India will not as a matter of course accord ex post facto sanction to irregular expenditure in circumstances in which they would not have been prepared to accord an original sanction. No. F. 366135. —The following resolution passed by the Secretary of State is published for general information :— In exercise of the powers conferred by paragraph (a) of sub-section (1) of Section 247 and sub-section (2) of section 257 of the Gov ernment of India Act, 1935, the Secretary of State for India, with the concurrence of his Advisers, hereby makes the following Rules, namely :— 1. (1) These rules may be called the Prema ture Retirement Rules. (2) They shall come into force on 1st April 1937. (3) Any previous rules made by the Secre tary of State in Council for the regulation of premature retirement on proportionate pension are hereby cancelled. 2. (1) The following officers may be per mitted by the Secretary of State to retire under these rules :— A. Any officer who, with effect from a date earlier than the date on which these rules come into force, was selected for or appointed to one of the services specified in entries (i) and (ii) or appointed to one of the posts specified in entries (iii), (iv) or (v) of the First Schedule, and who, if so selected or appointed after the 1st April 1924, was at the time of such selection or appointment of non-Asiatic domicile B. Any officer selected for or appointed to the Indian Civil Service or the Indian Police by the Secretary of State after the date on which these rules come into force and whose domicile at the time of such selection or appointment was non-Asiatic. Provided that— {a) no officer serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation, except an officer of the Railway Department, shall be eligible to retire under these rules— (i) before the establishment of the Federation, or (ii) if he is permanently employed in the Crown, External Affairs, Defence or Ecclesiastical Depart ment ; (&) no officer of the Regular Army in civil employ who is liable to recall to military employment, no officer of the Royal Indian Navy and no officer of the Indian Medical Service who ha« completed less than 17 years' total service, shall be eligible to retire under these rules unless the competent military or naval authorities are unable or un willing to absorb him in military or naval employment as the case may be ; (c) no officer of the Railway Department, shall be eligible to retire under these rules before the establishment of the Federal Railway Authority. {d) no officer serving in a department administered by a Governor in his discretion shall be eligible to retire under these rules while so employed ; (e) no officer shall be eligible to retire under these rules who is certified to be physically unfit for further service in India. (i2) If any doubt arises as to the date of any selection or appointment referred to in sub-rule (1) of this rule the matter shall be referred to the Secretary of State whose decision shall be final. 3. (1) Applications for such permission shall be addressed by officers serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation to the Gov ernor General, and by officers serving in connec tion with the affairs of a Province to the Governor. (2) An application under this rule may be submitted by an officer while he is on leave out of India, and in that case, unless the Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, considers his return to duty necessary before his application can be considered, the rules shall apply to him in the same manner as if his application had been submitted while on duty : Provided that an officer who has made an application under this rule while he is on leave out of India and whose application is sanctioned by the Secretary of State before his leave expires shall not be eligible for the gratuity described in Rule 12, except to the extent ad missible under sub-rule (6) of that rule. 4. On receipt of an application the Governor shall forward it with his recommendation to the Governor General, and the Governor General shall forward all applications other than those which have been cancelled under rule 7 whether received direct or through the Governor of a Province, with his recommendations for the orders of the Secretary of State. 5. An officer who has been permitted by the Secretary of State to retire under these rules, or whose application has been forwarded by the Governor General or the Governor with a recom mendation that his retirement be sanctioned, shall, ublests the Governor General in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation, or the Governor, in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of a Province, sees reason to the contrary, be permitted to avail himself, m anticipation of his retirement, of the full amount of leave which is due to him and which may be granted to him at one time (otherwise than on medical certificate) under the regulations for the time being in force and applicable to him : Provided that if the Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, considers thatleave in anticipation of retirement should not be granted, or that less than the full amount of leave available under regulations for the time being in force should be granted, the pro posal to withhold or reduce the leave applied for shall be submitted with the reasons there for for the orders of the Secretary of State. 6. (1) The Governor General or the Gov ernor, as the case may be, shall fix the date on which leave granted under rule 5 shall com mence : Provided that an officer who has been per mitted by the Secretary of State to retire under these rules shall not be detained in India beyond the date on which he desires to leave unless his detention cannot be avoided without prejudice to the public interest. (2) If the Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, considers that suitable arrangements cannot be made for the relief of any officer at the date on which he desires to proceed on leave preparatory to retirement under these rules, he may, when forwarding the application for the orders of the Secretary of State recommend that the Secretary of State should postpone the grant of permission and in that case shall specify the period of such post ponement. 7. An officer who has submitted an application for permission to retire under these rules shall not be at liberty to cancel his application and, if on leave, to return to duty without the con sent of the Governor General in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation or of the Governor in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of a Province. 8. (1) An officer who has submitted an appli cation for permission to retire under these rules may be permitted to take up other employment during the currency of his leave preparatory to retirement. (2) Such permission may be granted— (a) if the proposed employment lies in India, by the Governor General in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation or by the Governor in the case of officers servinar in connection with the affairs of a Province ; (&) if the proposed employment lies else where than in India, by the Secretary of State : Provided that an officer who has been granted permission to take up employment under this rule shall be precluded, save with the specific consent of the Secretary of State from with drawing his request for permission to retire and from returning to duty in India. (3) The Secretary of State, the Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, shall have the right to withhold permission to take up employment under this rule in cases where the employment appears to Vn'm to be such as could not with propriety be held by a person who is still in the service of the Crown in India ; or, alternatively, to grant the desired permission in any such case subject to such con ditions or restrictions as he may think necessary. 9. (1) The right of any officer to receive or retain a pension under the provisions of these rules is subject to the right of the Secretary of State— (a) to reduce or withhold any pension, if the past service of the applicant is not approved, or if the pensioner after re tirement is convicted of serious crime or is guilty of grave misconduct ; and (&) in cases where an officer obtains, prior to, or within two years from, the date of his retirement under these rules, other employment under the Crown, to suspend payment, wholly or in part, while the officer continues to be employed under the Crown, of the proportionate pension admissible under these rules. (2) In cases where a proportionate pension is suspended wholly or in part under clause (b) of the preceding sub-rule, the officer shall on the termination of his employment under the Crown receive the full proportionate pen sion under these rules in respect of his Indian service in addition to any pensionary award that mav be granted to him under the rules of the service in which he is employed after retir ing from the Indian service. (3) For the purposes of this rule, the expres sion ' employment under the Crown ' shall be deemed to include emplovment under the Gov ernments of Crown Colonies. Protectorates, and territories mandated to the British Government, but does not include employment under the Government of a self-srovernins |, Dominion or a State in India, or under a Local Authority. ^4) A proportionate pension shall not be liable to suspension either whollv or in part under sub-rule Cl> (h) of this rule unless the nronortionate -nensinn, when combined with the initial pav of the officer in his new appointment, would exceed three-fourths of the nav which he wonTd have drawn if he had remained on duty in India. 10. Subject to the provisions of Rule 9, a pensionable officer who has been permitted by the Secretary of State to retire under these rules shall be entitled, if he has completed less than five years' total service, to a gratuity equal to one month's pay (at the rate drawn by the applicant while last on duty before his retire ment), multiplied by the number of completed months of total service at the officer's credit and divided by 12, and converted at the rate of Is. 9d. per rupee ; and if, he has completed live years' total service, to a pension of the amount shown in the Second Schedule. 11. A non-pensionable officer of a Railway Service, Class I, who may be permitted to retire prematurely under these rules shall be entitled to the Railway contribution or bonus to his Provident Fund under the Provident Fund Rules of the Railway, and his gratuity under the Gratuity Rules calculated as if he had been invalided from service. If the officer has elected to subscribe to the Sterling Branch of the State Railway Provident Fund, the payment of the amount due under this rule shall be made in sterling at the rate and in the place prescribedin the State Railway Provident Fund (Ster ling Account) Rules, otherwise in rupees in India. 12. (1) In addition to the pension or gratuity referred to in rule 10 or the bonus and gratuity referred to in rule 11, any officer who has been permitted to retire under these rules (other than an officer who is entitled to the pension specified in the Second Schedule as the maximum pension admissible under these rules to the service to which he belongs and when more than one method of calculating a pension is prescribed, for the method of calculating the pension actually adopted), and who proceeds on retirement or on leave preparatory to retire ment to some part of the British Empire intend ing to settle there permanently, shall, subject to the provisions of rule 3 (2), be entitled to receive a gratuity equal to the cost, allowing for any special rebates admissible to railway officers, of first class fares and passages from the last place of his employment in India to his destina tion for himself, and for his wife and children if they were in India at the time of his proceed ing on retirement or leave preparatory to retire ment : Provided that except with the special sanction of the Secretary of State no gratuity shall be payable under this rule to an officer who is per mitted to retire or to proceed on leave prepara tory to retirement while employed elsewhere than in India and the amount of the gratuity (if any) payable to such an officer shall be such as the Secretary of ^State shall direct : Provided further that where there is no railway or steamer station at the last place of employment of an officer permitted to retire under these rules, the G6vernor General, in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of the Federation, and the Governor, in the case of officers serving in connection with the affairs of a Province, may include in the gratuity of such officers an amount equivalent to the mileage allowance for his journey to the nearest station which would have been admis sible to him under the travelling allowance rules applicable to him : Provided further that officers belonging to Railway services, class I, shall be entitled to 1st class passes in place of the cost of 1st class fares for railway journeys in India. (2) For purposes of payment of this gratuity to officers proceeding to or via the United Kingdom, first-class fares and passages shall be first-class steamer or railway fares to Bombay plus cost, allowing for any special rebates admis sible to railway officers, of first-class passage at B rates by the P. and 0. Steam Navigation Company to London (all sea route) ; and in addition, railway fares from London to destina tion. These rates are payable irrespective of the line or class by which an officer or his family travels. (3) Payment of the gratuity admissible under this rule (excluding that portion representing railway fares from London, which shall be paid by the High Commissioner), shall be made by the Governor General or the Governor, as the nase may be, before the officer leaves India. (4) The Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, may sanction the payment of a gratuity calculated as in sub-rules (1) and (2) of this rule, but excluding the fares and passages of the officer himself, to the families of officers who are obliged by climatic or ana logous reasons to leave later than the officer himself, or in advance of the officer but subse quent to the submission of his application to retire. (5) An officer who applies in India for per mission to retire and who is permitted to leave India in anticipation of the sanction of the Secretary of State is eligible for the gratuity. In such cases, if the officer proceeds to the United Kingdom, the Governor General or the Governor, as the case may be, shall authorise the High Commissioner to make payment. (6) Officers who apply to retire while on leave in England and whose families are in India at the time when their retirement was sanctioned by the Secretary of State shall receive a portion of the gratuity equal to the cost, allowing for any special rebates admissible to railway officers, of first-class railway fares and passages for their families when the latter leave India. (7) In no case shall a gratuity admissible under this rule or any portion thereof be pay able until the Secretary of State has sanctioned the officer's retirement under these rules. (8) The gratuity admissible under this rule shall be reduced by the value of any benefit received under the provisions of Schedule IV to the Superior Civil Service Rules in respect of the journey referred to in sub-rule (1) above. (9) The gratuity paid to an officer under this rule shall, in the event of his being per mitted to return to duty in India, be refunded. Such refunds may be made by deductions of 36 equal monthly instalments from the officer's pay-bill, commencing with the first pay-bill drawn after return. (10) For the purpose of this rule the term children means legitimate children or step children of an officer, whatever their age, who are wholly dependent on him. 13. (1) A member of the Indian Civil Ser vice who retires under these rules may adopt at his option any one of the three following methods of retaining for his wife and children benefits, admissible under the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Regulations, namely {a) He may cease to make any contribu tions and payments under the regula tions, and shall then retain only the right to a proportion of the contingent benefits under the regulations for his wife and children existing on the date of retirement, and for any children subsequently born to that wife. This proportion shall be equal to the num ber of his completed years' total service divided by 25, and the calculation shall be based upon the pension admissible to the widow of an officer of the class to which he belonged at the time of his retirement.(b) He may continue up to his 51st birth day to make contributions under the regulations at the rates payable by him at the date of retirement, and shall then retain the right to the full contingent benefits admissible under the regulations, according to his class on the date of his retirement for his wife existing at the date of retirement, and for any children by her, whether born before or after retirement. Under this alternative subscriptions will be payable under the ordinary regula tions for each child, whether born before or after retirement. In the event of the death of the wife, sub scriptions at the bachelor rate appro- i priate to the subscriber's class on retirement will be payable until the age of 51 : Provided fthat in the case of a subscriber appointed to the Service before 1st April, 1910, all such contributions shall cease with effect from the date on which he would have com pleted 25 years' service or from the 1st January, 1930, whichever is the later. (c) He may continue up to his 51st birth day to make contributions and pay ments under the regulations at the rates which would have been payable by him from time to time had he \ remained in the service. In that case he shall retain the full benefits admissible undqr the regulations as if he had remained in the service until death or retirement with an ordinary pension ; Provided that, in the event of the officer failing to notify within three months of the date of his retirement the method selected by him, he shall be deemed to have elected the first of the above methods. (2) The Secretary of State shall make good to the Indian Civil Service Family Pension Fund under a suitable procedure any loss which may be estimated to be thrown upon it by the, operation of this rule. 14. (1) An officer of the Indian Army or the Royal Indian Navy or of (the Indian Medical Service who retires under these, rules may select any one of the three following options with regard to his subscriptions under the Indian Military Service Family Pension Regula tions or to the Indian Military Widows' and Orphans' Fund :— (a) He may continue to subscribe^ at the half rate of subscription under Article 28 of the Indian Military Service Family Pension Regulations or rule 32 of the Indian Military Widows' and Orphans' Fund : or if a married subscriber under the Indian Military Service Family Pen sion Regulations, he may withdraw, receiving the refund authorised by Article 28. If he. continues to sub scribe he will retain the same rights to contingent benefits from the funds f V as if he had retired under the ordinary rules. (&) He may cease to make any payments under the regulations except in so far as is provided by the last sentence of this clause, and shall then retain the right to contingent benefits at the rates admissible under the re gulations to the widow and children of an officer of the class to which >>e belonged at the date of retirement, for his wife and children existing at that date, and for any children sub sequently born to that wife. Under this alternative, any donation pay able under the ordinary rules for any child born after retirement must, however, be paid by the, offic3r if he desires to retain any right to continuance of benefits for any such child. (c) He may continue up to his 55th birth day to make payments under the Regulations at the full rates ap plicable to the class which he would have attained had he, remained in the service until that date, and there after at half rates according to the class in which he is then subscribing. Any donation becoming due after the age of 55 will be payable in full as in the case of ordinary retire ments. His wife and children will in this case be eligible for the full benefits appropriate to the class in which he is subscribing at the date of death : Provided that in the event of the officer fail ing to notify within three months of the date of his retirement the, option selected by him lie shall be deemed to have selected the first of the above options. (2) The Secretary of State shall make good to the Indian Military Service Family Pension Scheme or the Indian Military Widows' and Orphans' Fund, ais the case may be, any loss which may be estimated to be thrown upon them by the operation of this rule. (3) The family of a military officer or of an officer of the Royal Indian Navy or the Indian Medical Service who retires under these Rules shall remain eligible for pensions under the Royal Warrant or under the corresponding rules laid down in Pension Regulations for the Army in India or in Regulations for the Royal India n Navy, whichever may be applicable if the officer had on retirement completed 20 years' service. If such an officer is permitted to retire under these Rules after completing less than 20 years' service, the Secretary of State shall, on the death of the officer, grant, subject to the conditions laid down in the Royal Warrant or in the rules referred to above (other than the condition requiring an officer to have completed 20 years' service in order to entitle his widow or children to pensions)— to his widow, a yearly pension of 701. divided by 20 and multiplied by a figure corresponding to the number of years total service completed bythe officer at the date of his retire ment ; and to each child, a pension of 16L divided by 20 and multiplied by a figure as aforesaid, or, in the case of a mother less child, a pension of 25^. divided by 20 and multiplied by a figure as aforesaid. 15. (1) An officer who is a subscriber, under Section II of the Superior Services (India; Family Pension Fund Rules and who retires with a pension under the Premature Retirement Rules may adopt, at his option, one of the follow ing methods of retaining for his wife and children benefits admissible under the Fund Rules, namely :— (a) He may cease to make any contribu tions under the rules, and shall then retain only the right to a proportion of the contingent benefits under the rules for his wife and children existing on the date of retirement, and for any children subsequently born to that wife. This proportion shall be equal to the number of completed years during which he has subscribed divided by 25. (&) He may continue until the expiration of 25 years from the date on which he became a subscriber to make con tributions under the rules at the rates which would have been payable by him from time to time had he remained in the Service. In that case he shall retain the full benefits admissible under the rules as if he had remained in the Service : Provided that, in the event of the officer failing tio notify within three months of the date of his retirement the method selected by him he shall be deemed to have elected the first of thet above methods. (2) The Secretary of State shall make good to the Superior Services (India) Family Pen sion Fund under a suitable procedure any ioss which may be estimated to be thrown upon it by the operation of this rule. 16. In the discharge of their functions under these rules, in so far as officers serving in con nection with the affairs of the Federation are concerned, the Governor General shall act in his individual judgment, and, in so far as officers serving in connection with the affairs of a Pro vince are concerned, the Governor General shall act in his discretion and the Governor in his individual judgment. 17. H72FinD—3,500—21-7-37—GIPSCopy of letter from the Government of India, Finance Department, New, Delhi, to the Under Secretary of State for India, Financial Department, India Office, London, No. F. 14 (1)-R. II |36, dated the 18th February 1937. Subject :— Proposed revision of certain Articles in the Civil Service Regulations relating to compensation pension. The Government of India have had under consideration the question of simplifying the various rules in the Civil Service Regulations relating to com pensation pension. 2. Article 426 of the Civil Service Regulations provides for the grant of a compensation pension under certain conditions. The difficulty in applying that Article is due to the fact that it does not explain what constitutes ' suitable 1 employment '. Further, the example given in the Note below the Article does not particularise what ' a temporary loss of pay ' may mean, nor what is meant by the phrase '' for a time ''. Again, the words 4 ' probable prospect of recover ing his former position after a time ' are not too precise. For practical pur poses, therefore, the ruling is unworkable. 3. The example in question allows for a pay in the new post which might be as much as 25 per cent, less than the pay drawn by the Government servant in the post abolished. Under Article 437, Civil Service Regulations, however, a Government Servant who has been granted a compensation pension is obliged to accept re-employment if the offer is made within six months from the date of his discharge ; his pension plus pay on re-employment must, however, be not less than the pay he drew at the time of his discharge. Thus there is a difference between the two Articles referred to. In the opinion of the Government of India there is no justification for that differentiation. 4. The existing rule that once an officer has gone on compensation pension he must accept any appointment which the Local Government thinks fit to offer him within six months of the date of his discharge or else forfeit his pension is not too reasonable and has the added disadvantage that opinions may differ as to what is, and what is not, ' suitable employment The Government of India consider that if a post is about to be brought under reduction Government should have the right to transfer the Government servant affected to another post the conditions of which are deemed by the authority competent to discharge him to be at least equal to those of his old appointment but if such a post cannot be found, it should be left entirely to the Government servant whether or not he takes the compensation pension or gratuity to which he is entitled for the service he has already rendered or whether he accepts further Government employment, even on a lower scale of pay and continues to count his previous service for pen sion. 5. It is also unnecessary to retain the provisions of the last two sentences of Article 426, Civil Service Regulations. Cases of reduction in the pay of a post should be dealt with under Fundamental Rule 23, and there should be no question of discharging an officer on compensation pension or gratuity in such cases. 6. Article 427 is wholly out of place in a body of service rules. It is merely an executive exhortation and not a rule governing conditions of service. The Government of India, therefore, consider that the opportunity should be taken while revising this particular group of rules in the Civil Service Regulations to delete Article 427. 7. The Government of India are further of the opinion that Article 514, Civil Service Regulations which was framed when the pay of posts was generally fixed is really unsuitable for dealing with posts borne on time-scales of pay. It is difficult to see the equity of saying that a person who is retrenched at a certain point in a scale of pay lower than the maximum and is given a compensation pension should, for all time, on re-employment, be limited to a maximum of pay plus pension equal to the point he had reached in the scale when he was retrenched, and whenever his pay reaches that point or exceeds it his pension ceases. To go on reducing the pension each time such an officer gets an incre ment is tantamount to stopping that officer's increments. The Government of India, therefore, propose that once the amount of the pension has been fixed in^ conformity with clause {a) of Article 514, Civil Service Regulations the officer should be entitled- to receive the benefits of increments in his new scale or post without a further corresponding reduction in the pension.2 8. The necessity for retaining Article 517 of the Civil Service Regnlations is doubtful. Once the pay and pension on re-employment have been hxed leave salary would be based on the pay drawn during acertamperwd ltis not equitable that a re-employed Government servant should be deprived during leave of the benefit of any increase m pay which he may have obtained due to increments or promotion so far as it is permissible under the operation of the ordinary rules governing the fixation of leave salary. There is no justification for restricting during the few months of leave what it is proposed to allow for the much longer period of duty. This would leave only one class of case in which the leave salary would be restricted by the operation of Article 517, namelv, that in which a Local Government exercises its powers under Article 514 a) of allowing a Government servant™ re-employment ma bona fide temporary duty to draw pension in whole or m part even though the sum total of pay and pension exceeds the pay which he was entitled to draw m his permanent post at the time of discharge. An officer on bona temporary dutv lasting for not more than a year does not earn much leave and it during th- 0 period of his re-employment he is allowed to draw leave salary pension in 'excess of what would ordinarily be admissible if he were employed perma nently, it is not necesary that, during the short period of leave that he earns by service, a restriction should be placed on the amount of leave salary to which he would otherwise be entitled on the basis of his pay. The Government of India consider therefore that for these reasons Article 517 should be deleted. 9. To give effect to the views expressed above, Articles 426, 427, 437, 439, 514, 515, and 517 of the Civil Service Regulations may be amended on the lines indicated in the enclosed draft. I am to mention that the views of the Local Governments have been obtained with regard to these proposals and subject to the criticisms which are explained below, the draft amendments have been accepted by all other Local Governments. 10. The Government of Bengal have suggested that Article 437 should not be deleted. The arguments in support of their suggestion are :— (1) that it is not always possible to find an officer, whose appointment is abolished, an alternative post immediately, but that an appoint ment such as he can ' reasonably and equitably be expected to accept ' often falls vacant within a short time ; (2) that the terms of Article 437 read with the proposed revised Article 514 provide sufficient safeguards to protect an officer from unfair dealings ; and (3) that the appointing authority can, in its discretion, decide whether the new appointment is, or is not, ' such as the officer cannot reasonably and equitably be expected to accept '. The grounds on which it is proposed to delete Article 437 are given in para graph 4 above. As the rule is considered unreasonable from the point of view of the Government servant and as the principles on which the rules regarding compensation pension were based, are being changed, it is considered that the deletion of the Article would be in accordance with those principles. Once a Govern ment servant has retired on compensation pension. Government should have no right to withdraw that pension. Further, all other Local Governments have accepted the proposal that Article 437 should be deleted and in the circumstances, the Government of India are of the opinion that the suggestion of the Government of Bengal should not be accepted. 11. The Government of Burma consider that it would be desirable in Article 426 to indicate at what time the offer of another post at least equal to the old post is to be made. They have suggested that such an offer shouhi be made at the time of discharge or earlier and that in order to cover this point, the words ' without interruption of service ' should be inserted after the word ' appointed ' in the redraft of Article 426. It follow? from the terms of this draft Article that there will be no break in the service of an officer who is selected for discharge owing to the abolition of his post and is appointed to the other like post, and that the service will be continuous. The insertion of the words suggested by the Government of Burma might lead to difficulties and the Government of India propose that the draft Article should not be amended as suggested by the Local Government.3 12.1 am to request that the orders of the Secretary of State may be obtained on the amendments to the various Articles on the lines indicated in the enclosed draft. The Governor General in Council and Local Governments pro pose to issue in due course substantially similar amendments for services under their rule-making control. In exercise of the powers conferred by sub-section (1) of Section 247 of the Government of India Act, 1935, the Secretary of State, with the concurrence of his Advisers, hereby makes the following amendments to the Civil Service Regulations made by the Secretary of State in Council under Section 96-B. of the Government of India Act, 1919, and directs that the amendments shall have effect from 9th June 1937. 1. For Article 426 of the said Regulations and the note thereunder the following shall be substituted, namely :— ''If an officer is selected for discharge owing to the abolition of his permanent post, he shall, unless he is appointed to another post the conditions of which are deemed to .be at least equal to those of his own, have the option (a) of taking any compensation pension or gratuity to which he may be entitled for the service he has rendered, or {b) of accepting another appointment on such pay as may be offered,, and continuing to count his previous service for pension.' 2. Articles 427, 437 and 439 shall be omitted. 3. For clause (a) of Article 514 of the said Regulations the following shall be substituted, namely :— ' An officer who has obtained a compensation pension, if re-employed, may retain his pension in addition to his pay, provided that if he is re-employed in a post paid from general revenues, the pension shall remain wholly or partly in abeyance if the sum of the pension and the initial pay on re-employment exceeds his substantive pay at the time of his discharge, that is, an officer can draw so much of pension only as will make his initial pay plus pension equal to his substantive' pay at the time of his discharge. Once the amount of the pension has been fixed in conformity with the above _ con dition the officer shall be entitled to receive the benefits of incre ments in his new scale or promotion to another scale or post with out a further corresponding reduction in pension : nor shall the amount of pension so fixed be varied during leave. In the case, however, of a pensioner re-employed in either a permanent or a temporary appointment, for bona fide temporary duty lasting for not more than a year, the Local Government may allow the pen sion to be drawn in whole or in part even though the sum total of pay and pension exceeds his substantive pay at the time of his discharge.'' 4. Article 517 of the said Regulations shall be omitted. H72FiaD—3,500—20-7-37—GIPSA c '' R16S. P. Ct , MOe 32. Simla, the 29th July 1937, Subject Desirability of associating an independent authority with a depejrtmental officer conduct ing an enquiry under rule 55 of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) ' Rules. Sir, I am directed to say that, in a recent case in which a Provincial Government decided to proceed against an officer of an All-India Service under rule 55 of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, the enquiry prescribed in that rule was entrusted solely to a departmental officer subordinate to the officers who had at different times already expressed an adverse opinion on the officer against whom proceedings were taken. No. F.-322/II/35-Ests. —In exercise of the powers conferred by sub- •section (3) of section 266 of the Government of India Act, 1985, the •Governor General in his discretion is pleased to make the following regu lations : — 1. These regulations may be called the Federal Public Service Commis sion (Consultation by the Governor General) Eegulations. 2. It shall not be necessary to consult the Commission in regard to any of the matters mentioned in clauses (a) and {b) ot sub-section (3) of •section 266 of the Government oi India Act, 1935, in the case of (t) the services and posts specified in the Schedule to these regula tions, or (ii) any post to which the Governor General is empowered to make an appointment in his discretion or exercising his individual judgment. 3. It shall not be necessary to consult the Commission in regard to the selection for appointment: — (a) to a Central Service, Class I, of any officer of His Majesty's Forces or any officer who is already a member of an All-India Service, a Central Service, Class I, a Eailway Service, Class I, or a Service under the Crown Department corresponding to a Central Service, Class I; (h) to a Central Service, Class II, of any officer by transfer from another Central Service, Class II, or by promotion from a subordinate service; or by transfer or promotion from cor responding services under the Crown Department; fc) to a tenure post in a Central Service, Class I, or a Central Service, Class II, of an officer of a Provincial Service; (d) otherwise than in accordance with one of the methods mention ed in (a), (b) or (c) above, to the services or posts specified in the Schedule. 4. Notwithstanding anything contained in rule 3 it shall not be neces- rsary to consult the Commission in the following cases: (a) in regard to the selection for appointment to any post where the selection is made in England by or through the High Com missioner for India; (h) in regard to the selection for appointment to a temporary posu« if the post is not likely to last for more than one year, or m the case of an appointment for a period of more than one year but less than three years, if the Commission advises that the appointment may be made without consulting them.o Provided that, if a temporary appointment is extended beyond the? period for which it was initially made, the period of the appointment shall, for the purposes of this rule, be reckoned from the date when it was originally made and not from the date of the extension thereof. 5. It shall not be necessary to consult the Commission before an order is passed in any disciplinary case other than—- (a) an original order by the Governor General imposing any of the- following penalties: — (i) Withholding of increments or promotion, including stoppage- at an efficiency bar, (n) Eeduction to a lower post or time-scale, or to a lower stage- in a time-scale; {in) Recovery from pay of the whole or part of any pecuniary loss caused to Government by negligence or breach of' orders; {iv) removal from service; or (v) dismissal; (b) an order by the Governor General on an appeal; or (c) an order by the Governor General, proposed to be made in response to any petition or memorial, overruling or modifying: the order of a subordinate authority. Provided that it shall not be necessary for the Governor General to consult the Commission in cases relating to civilian personnel paid from the Defence Services estimates. 6. CHETTUR, Under Secy, to the Govt, of India, H71FmP—3,600—2X-7-37—GIPSCopy of letter from the Government of India, Finance Department, to the Under Secretary of State for India, Financial Department, India Office, No. F. 6 (82) -E. HjS'S, dated the 2 nd January 1936. Subject Proposed amendment of clause {b) of Article 526 of the Civil Service Regulations. I am directed to refer to the Secretary of State's Despatch No. 5-Financial, dated the 1st June 1933, axnending inter alia Article 526 of the Civil Service Regulations. It has now been brought to the notice of the G-overnment of India that clause {b) of the Article as then amended is ultra vires, in so far as it relates to British warrant non-commissioned officers and men and possibly also to British service officers. It is understood that when a British Othpr Rank is discharged to pension, the Chelsea Hospital authorities regard them selves as not being empowered save under the terms of the Royal Warrant to withhold the pension and in view of this, neither the Government of India nor a Local Government can be empowered to withhold the pension. Further, there is *dri anomaly as regards the position under the old and the revised Article 526 {h), Civil Service Regulations as regards the basis of the calcula tion of the civil pension of a military pensioner continued in civil employ. 2. Cases have arisen in which officers have earned a military pension during their civil employment and yet continued in civil employment and therefore it is necessary to legislate for them in a way that is not only fair but legal. The Government of India have, therefore, reconsidered afresh the question of revising clause (&) of Article 526, Civil Service Regulations in order to remove the defects mentioned in paragraph 1 above. The following two alternatives have been considered in this connection :— {a) to amend Article 526 {b) so as to limit its scope to pensions payable from Indian revenues, and to add a new sub-clause (c) governing pensions or portions of pensions payable by the Home estimates. In this new sub-clause (c) provision would have to be made to allow such pensions to be drawn from the date they are earned, and the question would then arise whether the amount of such a pension should be taken into consideration with a view to a reduc tion in the civil pay of the officer during continued employment, or (6) to abrogate the principle on which clause (b) of Article 526 is based and bring all officers who earn a military pension while in civil employ under the same principle as is laid down in Article 526 (a) for those who have already earned a military pension before they are employed in a civil capacity. The Government of India are in favour of the adoption of alternative (b). The objection to alternative (a) is that it would give rise to differential treat ment of officers who have earned a pension payable by Home estimates as com: pared with those who have earned a military pension payable by Indian estimates. Also if, as would have to be done, the' pay in continued civil employment of those in the new category—sub-clause (c)—be reduced in con sideration of the military pension they would draw, then they would earn a lower civil pension for their civil employment than those whose pensions are payable by Indian revenues and who would remain governed by the existing sub-clause (b). Further, the anomaly pointed out in paragraph 1 above will remain intact. The only objection to alternative (b) is that, as the pay of the officers would be reduced in view of the military pension drawn, they would draw a lower civil pension based on the lower civil pay than they can do at present under existing clause (b). There is little force in this objection since, as will be seen from paragraph 1 above, clause (b) as amended by the Secretary of State in Council in 1933 gave an unintentional concession. 3. In this Department Despatch to the Secretary of State No. 9, dated tho 22nd December 1932, justification was shown for making a differentiation between the military pensioner who is employed in the civil after earning a military pension and the person who earns a military pension while in civil employment and continues in civil employment. It is arguable that there is justification for making such a differentiation if the necessity for differentia tion arises but it is considered that no such necessity does arise. If an officerearns a military pension while in civil employ, it means that upto that date his civil service has not been qualifying tor a civil pension, because an ofiicer cannot earn two ordinary pensions ai once. His civil pensionaoie service must, theretore, start to run irorn tiie day atier he nas earned his military pension, 'ine Government of india see no necessity for nolding that tnat civil pension must be based on a higner civil pay tnan the omcer would have been entitled to draw under Article oAti {a) it ne had earned his military pension before ne entered civil employ. If the officer, in view of being allowed to draw his mili tary pension, has His civil pay reduced and does not like it, it is open to mm to decline to serve. The conclusion of the (iovernment of India is, thereiore, that by tar the simplest remedy is alternative (6). in order to give elfect to this, tney submit for the consideration of the Secretary of State m Council a draft amendment of clause (6) of Article 52(3. The Grovernment of India recommmd that the amended rule may apply with retrospective effect from the 3Uth May 1933 to military pensioners wnose continued employment in a Civil Department started after tnat date and who are in civil employ on the date on which the rule is amended. If this is not done and the amended rule is made applicable in cases in which continued employment begins from the date the rule is amended, the claim to pay and pension m the Civil Department of British Service Officers, 'Warrant and non-commissioned officers and men who earned or will earn a military pension while in civil employ after the revi sion of Article 526 (6), Civil Service Regulations in 1933 but up to the date of the passing of the proposed amended rule, will continue to be regulated by the existing Article which in so far as it aft'ects the British Service Officers has been held to be ultra vires. The proper course therefore appears to be to apply the proposed rule with retrospective effect as suggested. It is, however, not proposed to reopen the case of men who cease to be in civil employ before the amended rule is promulgated. 4. The Government of India propose to promulgate a similar amendment in respect of the services under the rule-making control of the Governor- General in Council and to invite Local Governments to take similar action in respect of their services. The amendment will adversely affect members of the services under the rule-making control of the Governor-General in Council, who were in service on the 27th May 1930, and those under the rule-making control of Local Governments who were in service on the 9th March 1926 and I am to request that the Secretary of State in Council may kindly be moved to accord his sanction, under Rule 9 of the Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, to the issue by the Governor-General in Council and Local Governments of such an amendment. Amendment to the Civil Service Regulations. For clause (6) of Article 526, the following shall be substituted :— ' (h) A military officer, departmental officer, warrant or non-commissioned officer or soldier who earns a pension under military rules while he is in civil employ, shall draw such pension while he is in civil employ, but the authority competent to fix the pay and allowances of the post in civil employ may, with effect from the date on which the officer or soldier becomes entitled to the pension, alter such pay and allowances with reference to such officer or soldier after taking into account the amount of the pension '. Copy of demi-official, letter from F. E. Gkist, Esq,., Financial Secret art, India Office, Whitehall, to W. Christie, Esq., M.C., I.C.S., Deputy Sec retary to the Government of Indla, Finance Department, No. F. 481 1 36, dated the 6 th february 1936. Will you kindly refer to your official letter of the 2nd January 1936, No. F. 6 (82) |R. II135, regarding the re-employment of military officers in Civil Depart ments. We agree that the second of the two courses suggested by the Govern ment of India is the better, but before submitting the proposals for the con sideration of the Secretary of State in Council, there are two points on whiich we should like to have some further information. 2. The draft amendment speaks of a military officer, etc., who ' earns a pen sion under military rules '', and we are not quite clear whether by this the Gov ernment of India intend that the officer or soldier should be required to retire or take his discharge from the Service as soon as he has qualified for a militarys pension, or whether it is intended to retain him in the Army, if he is an officer until he reaches the age for compulsory retirement or, if he is a soldier until he can claim discharge with pension. From the point of view of the Civil Depart ment, the former course has advantages inasmuch as it enables the employing authority to make a saving in pay charges at the expense of Army estimates and possibly of the War Office, corresponding to the amount of military pension in issue, but it might conflict with the rule in the Civil Service Regulations which forbids a Government Servant to retire voluntarily from the Service in order to take up another post and draw pension in, addition to pay, and the Govern ment of India may think it desirable to apply the principle of this rule to the cases now under discussion. In that event some amendment of the draft sub mitted by the Government of India would be necessary, as it would be possible. as it is at present worded, for an officer or other rank with the connivance of the employing authority to draw the full pay of a civil post plus military pension. 3. If the intention were to reduce the pay of the post by the amount of the pension the officer or soldier might very well object to being required to retire from the Army on a lower rate of pension than he could earn by further military service, unless he were sure of receiving a proportionately higher civil pension as the result of his civil service rendered after retirement from the Army. 4. The second point relates to the question raised in the last sub-paragraph of paragraph 2 of your letter. It is true that, the adoption of the course pro posed by the Government of India would, as regards civil pension, bring those coming under Article 526 (b) into line with those coming under Article 526 (a), but the effect is .that the re-employing authority escapes a part of what might be regarded as the normal pension liability of the civil post, because the pay of that post has been reduced by the amount of pension earned by army service, but here, unlike the saving in pay charges, the saving is made at the expense of the officer or other rank. We are inclined to think that, subject to any considerations the Government of India may wish to urge to the contrary, both rules require some modification in this respect. It does not seem to us lo be equitable that the civil pension should be calculated on anything less than the full pay of the post—or^ the unreduced pay of the officer if he is on a time-scale rate of pay. We think it should be ruled that notwithstanding any reduction of civil pay made in accordance with the provisions of these two paragraphs of Article 526, the civil pension of the incumbent should be calculated on the full civil pay of the post. We do not know what view the Secretary of State in Council would take of the point, but it would be useful to have the considered view of the Government of India to place before him when the case is submitted for decision. I imagine that in practice the point arises only in connection with other ranks, and possibly departmental officers, as Indian Army, Koyal Engi neer and Indian Medical Service officers in civil employ continue to earn pension under military rules. As regards the point raised in paragraphs 2 and 3 of your letter that the intention underlying the phrase ' earns a pension under military rules ' is not quite clear, I may say that we did not contemplate any departure from the principle enunciated in Article 509A of the Civil Service Regulations and that it was not the intention that military personnel in civil employ should be made to retire from the Army sooner than they would have done in the ordinarv course. As, however, the phrase used in our draft amendment mio-ht be inter preted to mean this, I suggest that it might be amended with advantage to who is granted a pension under military rules '. This would remove anv suspicion that the new rule is intended to force military personnel to retire from the Army sooner than they would in the ordinary course of events and consequently on a lower military pension than they could otherwise earn If this suggestion is accepted it will be necessary to substitute the words 'whoV o is granted a pension under military rules ' for the words ^ who earns a pen sion under military rules ' occurring in line 3 of the re-draft of clause (h) of Article 526 which was forwarded with our letter of the 2nd January. It will also be necessary with a view to keeping up the same phraseology that the words from which the pension is granted ' should be substituted for the words ' on which the officer or soldier becomes entitled to the pension ' in lines 8-9 of the redraft, and that the words after he has been granted a pension under military rules ' should be substituted for the words ' after he has earned a pension under military rules ' occurring in the first sentence of Article 525. 3. You have observed that it would be possible under the draft amendment as it stands for an officer or other rank to draw the full pay of the post plus military pension with the connivance of the employing authority. I admit that the rule is not mandatory and that had we contemplated any departure from the principle that a Government servant should not be allowed to retire voluntarily from service in order to take up another post and draw pension in addition to pay, we might have run the risk pointed out by you, but we have no intention of going back on the principle laid down in Article 509A. As for the amendment not being mandatory, the power to fix the civil pay of such Government servants vests in the authority competent to fix the pay and allowances of the civil post which is generally an authority higher than the employing authority, and such authority may be expected to exercise its discre tion judiciously. In any case the position is not different from that under Article 526 {a) and the Government of India consider that it is not necessary to prescribe any hard and fast rule regarding the proportion of military pension which must be deducted from civil pay. 4. As regards the point raised in the last paragraph of your letter that pension in the civil department should be based not on the civil pay for a military pensioner as reduced after taking into consideration the military pen sion but on the pay he would have drawn in the civil post had he not drawn a military pension. The question had been considered already by the Govern ment of India before they approached the India Office with the recommendation made in their letter, dated the 2nd January 1936, and they arrived at the con clusion that no departure should be made from the accepted principles of Article 486, Civil Service Regulations, in view of the fact that only a few individuals were likely to earn civil pension and that those who did not like the reduction in their civil pay with its resultant effect on civil pension need not continue in civil employ. As stated in our letter of the 2nd January, the exist ing Article 526 (&) gave an unintentional concession so far as the basis of the calculation of the civil pension of a military officer continued in civil employ was concerned. Under the old Article the civil pension was calculated on the pay of the civil appointment reduced by the amount of the military pension. The revision proposed by the Government of India therefore aims at restoring this position by withdrawing this unintentional concession and they would reaffirm the view already expressed that the civil pension should be based on the pay actually drawn and not on the unreduced pay of the post. One point, however has arisen in this connection which needs mention. Except as provided by rules 61 and 64, a Government servant transferred to a Service or post to which the rules in Sections I to V of this Chapter apply, from a Ser vice or post to which they do not apply, remains under the leave rules to which he Was subject prior to his transfer ; provided that it shall be open to him at the time of the transfer or any time thereafter to exercise the option of coming under the rules in Sections I to V of this Chapter, subject to the con dition that all leave at his credit on the date on which he comes under these rules shall lapse. physicalDescription.extent: File papers are arranged chronologically, according to the date they were circulated to the Political Agent, Bahrain and others. They are followed by file notes (folios 269-272) which include a partial list of the later documents in the file, together with their unique document reference number to help identify them. The list also records both the folio number and the simple reference number from 1 to 12, which has been written on the documents, usually the circulation slips, in red or blue crayon and encircled. The pencilled folio numbers and the red and blue document numbers help to locate specific documents in the file. The list records either the main or secondary foliation number.

Foliation: numbered 1A, 1B, 1C, 2-273. The number 155 has been omitted. The numbering is written in pencil in the top right corner of the folio, starting at the front of the file, on the file cover (f 1A) and ending on the inside cover at the back of the file (f 273).There is an incomplete, secondary foliation sequence. The latest documents at the back of the file (folios 235-268) were originally numbered 225 to 257 in pencil in the top right corner.Condtion: folios 9 and 27 are damaged. The torn right hand edge along the length of folio 9 obliterates a few word endings. The torn bottom edge along the length of folio 27 obliterates one or more words in the bottom right corner.

mods.abstract: The file contains Government of India circular letters, memoranda and notices that were issued mainly by the Finance and Home Departments in 1937 and 1938. There are also circulars from the Office of the Accountant-General, Central Revenues, the Department of Education, Health and Lands, the Railway Department and others. The earliest enclosure in the file is a letter dated 2 June 1931 that was recirculated in 1937 (folio 22).The circulars contain regulations, rules, procedures, interpretation and guidance about personnel matters such as pension entitlements, air and sea passage concessions, medical leave, treatment and expenses and other service conditions of Government of India employees, as follows:The Premature Retirement Rules, 1937;Numerous amendments to the Fundamental Rules;Several amendments to the Civil Service Regulations;Several amendments to the Revised Leave Rules, 1933;Several amendments to the Study Leave Rules and the Legal Study Rules, 1937;Several amendments to the Central Subordinate (Inferior) Services (Gratuity, Pension and Retirement) Rules, 1936;Amendments to the Indian Civil Service (Non-European Members) Provident Fund Rules;Procedure to follow under the Civil Account Code for the investigation and payment of claims to arrears of pay, allowances and increments;Interpretation of the rules relating to the grant of travelling allowance for journeys by road instead of rail;Policy on taking disciplinary action, under the Government Servants' Conduct Rules, against employees who have personal financial debts that are subject to debt recovery proceedings by their lenders;Interpretation of accounting rules that regulate the conditions under which a department of government may make charges for services or articles it has supplied and the procedure for recording such charges in Government accounts;Reciprocal arrangements between the Government of India and the Government of Bombay regarding medical treatment and fees in cases where their respective personnel become ill in the other Government’s territory;Procedures relating to the medical examination of Central Government employees for their fitness to work prior to appointment, or for other reasons;Travelling allowance rules regarding the rail fares and class of travel permissible for persons travelling with a high official.
